div1.p: In the Circuit Court of the United States for the W. Dist of Washington Northern Division
In the matter of the application of Columia George for a writ of habeas corpus
Filed in the U.S. Circuit Court. APR 27 1906, A. Reeves Ayres, Clerk. By HM Matthew, Deputy
In the United States Circuit Court for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the Matter of the Application of Columbia George, for a writ of Habeas Corpus. No. 1390.
Order Denying Application for Writ of Habeas Corpus, Queshing Order to Show Cause and Dismissing Petition

In this matter it appearing that the petitioner, Columbia George, filed his petition for a writ fo habeas corpus, claiming that he was unlawfully imprioned, detained and confined and restrained of his liberty by Charles B. Hopkins, United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, at the United States Penitentiary on McNeill's Island, in the State of Washington, and praying that a writ of habeas corpus issue, directed to the said United States Marshal commanding him to have the body of said petitioner before the judge of the above entitled court, at a time and place to be specified; that thereafter, to-wit, on the 23rd day of March 1906, an order was issued directed to Charles B. Hopkins, United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, ordering and directing him to be and appear before the judge of the above entitled court on the 26th day of March 1906 and show cause, if any, why the writ of habeas corpus should not be issued as prayed for in said petition; that thereafter, to-writ, on the 26th day of March 1906, upon the application of the United States Attorney for the Western District of Washignton, an order was duly made and entered in the premises, allowing the United States to intervene, answer and defend the said petition

and said order to show cause, and that thereafter, on said 26th day of March 1906, the said United States Marshal, and the United States, filed thier answer and return to the said petition and order to show cause, setting forth among other things, that said petitioner, Columbia George, was in the legal custody of the said Untied States Marshal, and taht he was being legally confined in the United States Penitentiary on McNeill's Island, and praying that the rule and order to show cause issued in this matter on the 23rd day of March 1906, the said petitioner filed a reply to the said answer and return of the said United States Marshal and the United States, and thereafter, to-wit, on the 26th day of March 1906, the said matter was brought on for hearing, the petitioenr, Columbia George, appearing by his counsel, R.J. Slater, and the United States and the said United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, appearing by Jesse A. Frye, United States Attorney for the Western District of Washington; that after hearing argument of counsel, the court took the same under advisement and thereafter, to-wit, on the 13th day of April 1906, the judge of the above entitled court filed his memorandum of decision in the above entiled cause, holding that the application of the said Columbia George for writ of habeas corpus, be denied, and the order to show cause heretofore issued, be quashed and said petition dismissed; and the Court being fully advised in the premises, and all things here understood:
Now, Therefore, It is hereby ordered and adjudged, that the application of the said Columbia George for a writ of habeas corpus herein, be, and the same hereby is, denied.
And it is Further Ordered and Adjudged, that the order to show cause heretofore issued in this cause be, and the same hereby is, quashed.
And it is Further Ordered and Adjudged, that the petition for a writ fo habeas corpus of the said Columbia George filed herein on the 24th day of February 1906, be, and the same hereby is, dismissed.
Done in open Court this 27th day of April 1906.

To which ruling, orders and judgement of the above entitled court, the petitioner, Columbia George, excepts, for the reason that said ruling, orders and judgement are not supported by the facts in the case, and are not supported by the law controlling the cause, and are contrary to the law controlling the case, which exceptions are this day allowed.
Dated, Seattle, Washington, this 27th day of April 1906.
